sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for the Predicate negation (this would include progressive and future prefix). (e.g. miš, ma, mū ).

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found
updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

cit.quote: Today the weather is not very hot

wib:featureValueObservation.note: The example is from a 64 year-old male from the Nʕēm tribe, yet the value for predicate negation could be applied to speakers from this community from all sociolinguistic profiles and ages.

cit.quote: I am speaking now, I am not free

wib:featureValueObservation.note: The example is from a 62 year-old female speaker from the Nʕēm tribe. This value for predicate negation could be applied to middle age and old speakers speakers from this community. Generally not as frequent among young speakers.

cit.quote: it (m) is not at my time/era
no, it is not a specific day
k̬bīri šway yaʕni may ṣabī may wal[ɛd̥ʰ]
Yes, she is a bit old, that’s to say (she is) not a young girl, not a young child
dabčət ʔal-ʔaṛaḅ ʔənd-nä l-aš-šyūx ʔač-čibīrä mo məṯl ad-dabčāt ʔal-ḥd̠̣əriyyä
Our dabkes are for big cheikhs, not like the "sedentary" dabkes

wib:featureValueObservation.note: It is used before prepositions, adjectives, for sentential negation in the iussive mood

cit.quote: don´t you go telling them the story

wib:featureValueObservation.note: "Mū can replace miš in all the uses of miš but it is used less frequently." (Al-Wer 2007:9)
It is considered a Koine form
It is used to negate particles

With l-, maʕ, and ʕind we find also mā, mā...š, and ..š and a-š are also found but just with maʕ: ən-nās mā maḥ-ḥa flūs "people do not have money", ma ʕind-ī-š tilifōn-o "I do not have his number", law maʕ-kī-š ṣafaṭ duxxān btuṭlub sikāra min ʕand wāḥad? "If you have not cigharettes with you, do you ask a cigarette to someone?"
Mā is used with a locative or existential predicate.
Mu and muš are used with equative predicates, participles, and comparativ predicates. Mu and mush can be used invariably with any person, muš being more common in text counts

cit.quote: the families are big not small

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Mu and muš are used with equative predicates, participles, and comparativ predicates. Mu and mush can be used invariably with any person, muš being more common in text counts
Can be considered as a Koine form

cit.quote: ̱ḏahab ṭalaʕ zayy ḥǧār yaʕni miš ḏahab
gold was appearing under the form of stones, not gold
before they used to dance the šaḥge not the dabka
it is not far from us
the weather in Istanbul is not good
i do not do anything at all
that is not him, apparently it is someone else

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Maltese orthography: id-dar mhix kbira
Maltese orthography: ir-raġel mhux ħelu

cit.quote: Muhammad is not in the house
If you fall, it's not my problem
It is not known how much

wib:featureValueObservation.note: mūb is also attested

cit.quote: Girls who went to school were (considered) worth nothing
That part doesn't belong to this house

wib:featureValueObservation.note: The feminine form mahīb exists but it is not as productive as the masculine form, which is employed for both genders

cit.quote: The fault was not this man's

wib:featureValueObservation.note: The feminine form hīb exists but it is not as productive as the masculine form, which is employed for both genders

cit.quote: mā tčūf-ha, killiš mā tčūf-ha, mā tibayyin - humb al-ḥīn
You didn't see her, you never saw her, she never appeared - not like now
mā hu ani, mā hu inta tirzik-na
It's not me, and it's not you, that sustains us

wib:featureValueObservation.note: mā hi is the feminine singular counterpart, whereas mā hum is the plural counterpart

cit.quote: The old days weren't like now

wib:featureValueObservation.note: mi is the feminine singular counterpart. The singular gender distinction no longer exists in the urban Baḥārna dialects, whereas in the village dialects the gender distinction is retained

cit.quote: Even the old women won't agree

wib:featureValueObservation.note: mihi is the feminine singular counterpart, whereas muhum/mihim is the plural counterpart
"Occasionally this negative varies for gender in the singular: mu (mhu) zeen, mi (mhi) zeena." (Johnstone 1967:148)
This is less frequently attested than mu

cit.quote: There is no difference between them

wib:featureValueObservation.note: This is only occasionally employed

cit.quote: Is this not a bad (forbidden) thing?
We do not have the intention to come to Benghazi
He will not finish his work

wib:featureValueObservation.note: miš in most cases, occasionally only -š can be attached to the noun phrase to negate a presumption, similar to Cairene Arabic(Schroepfer 2022:272)

cit.quote: This child ist not my brother
He is not the neighbour by the house.

wib:featureValueObservation.note: also mūši
masi
deduced from texts
Deduced from example.

cit.quote: If our mothers are not at home.

wib:featureValueObservation.note: This form is probably due to an influence from the Šarqīya region.
mā and lā negate verbs, nouns and adverbs.
mā and lā negate verbs, nouns and adverbs.
Deduced from an example.

cit.quote: no, no, it is not forbidden

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Miš or maš
